overview.short: Salmonella are Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic rods within Enterobacterales, classically non-lactose fermenting and often H2S-producing.
overview.clinical_context: Major causes of gastroenteritis and enteric fever; infections range from self-limited diarrhea to invasive systemic disease.

field_notes.H2S: Many Salmonella produce H2S (blackening on XLD/HE/TSI), but not all isolates do.
field_notes.Capsule: Vi capsule is associated with S. Typhi (and some Paratyphi C), not typical for non-typhoidal Salmonella.

key_differentiators.notes: Non-lactose fermentation supports Salmonella over common coliforms.
H2S positivity supports Salmonella over Shigella (typically H2S negative).
LDC positivity helps separate Salmonella from some Citrobacter with overlapping colony appearance.

common_confusions.reason: Overlap in non-lactose fermentation and possible H2S production on selective media.
Some Proteus are non-lactose fermenters and H2S positive; swarming and urease positivity argue for Proteus.
Both can be non-lactose fermenters; Shigella is typically non-motile and H2S negative.

when_to_question_identification: Urease positivity suggests Proteus or related genera.
Strong lactose fermentation argues against Salmonella.
Non-motile isolate makes Shigella more likely (though confirm with full profile).
Oxidase positivity argues against Enterobacterales (including Salmonella).

recommended_next_tests.reason: Required to assign serovar (e.g., Enteritidis, Typhimurium, Typhi).
recommended_next_tests.api_kit: SSI Diagnostica Salmonella O and H antisera

recommended_next_tests.reason: Common molecular confirmation for Salmonella genus.
